But on a less whiny note, I've been experimenting with sleight of hand with dogs and cats for several years and have found the "French Drop" method of vanishing a treat fools 50 percent of the animals consistently. Also, the animals that are fooled don't seem to be able to learn that they are being fooled. About 50 percent of those animals lose interest, the others continue being fooled.
Small children on the other hand seem to be fooled 100 percent of the time but quickly learn they are being fooled and seek an explanation.
It would not be hard to show the birds what normal movement of an object looks like in human hands and then later show the tricks and see the reaction.

I always like to think that magicians are playing tricks with our perception of persistance.

While we make fun of babies because they might lack it. (That is why, if the object is not on its sight, it means the object disappeared in his perspective).

But this can be a problem as well. Magicians know that, for example, they do slight of hand to make you think the object is persisting on one hand when it is, in fact, on the other.

Babies, from the moment you take it out of sight, it would think the object disappeared and wouldn't remember it. So vanishing it wouldn't be surprising.

Only for someone with persistance cognition would be fooled by it (as we have seen in humans and monkeys)

I don't know if this is particularly true or helpful but in my experience humans are able to react much faster to sound then eyesight and even faster with touch than sound. I don't know if this is because of processing time or something else but it is still interesting. An example of this is with the monster hunter series if you use visual cues for your actions with some monsters or mini games you will never be able to react quickly enough to avoid certain attacks or activate the event at the correct time but if you use your ears and the vibration of controllers you can easily avoid the attack or activate the event. This is mostly just personal experience but everyone who uses the cues I just mentioned to take an action will be successful and those who use only visual cues are not. This might be intentional design to more fully engage with the player but the fact that you have people who do similar things to that with other video games and other media makes me think that there might be something to it.

I worked at this industrial complex. It was just a larg set of buildings, set up for rent. They had a common outside eating area, with picnic tables and garbage cans. One guy was feeding the birds, which was interesting to watch. The eating area was near a large wooded area. Crow, maybe ravens would come out, and watch us eat. We would put our left over food out for the crows, but they never touched that. I don't they trusted us. Thing is, they would take food out of the trash, and eat that. On guy was eating bread cheese stick out of paper box. He had four left. He put them in the box, and threw them out.  The crow flew right down, and popped the box open. He took out the four bread sticks, and and a paper napkin. He stacked the cheese stick, so he could grab them all, but there was to many. Then sea gulls started show up. That's when the crow ripped out chunks of paper towl, and threw them. The wind took the bits of paper towl, and sea gulls chased them. The crow kept biting off the ends of the cheese sticks. Why I don't know, but after the seaguls realized the bit of paper wasn't food, they came back. The crow ripped another chunk of paper towl, and let the wind talk it. The crow finally ate one cheese stick, and reduce the size of the other. It let go of the paper towl, and seaguls chased that, as the crow flew away.

Every great magic trick consists of three parts or acts. The first part is called "The Pledge". The magician shows you something ordinary: a deck of cards, a bird or a man. He shows you this object. Perhaps he asks you to inspect it to see if it is indeed real, unaltered, normal. But of course... it probably isn't. The second act is called "The Turn". The magician takes the ordinary something and makes it do something extraordinary. Now you're looking for the secret... but you won't find it, because of course you're not really looking. You don't really want to know. You want to be fooled. But you wouldn't clap yet. Because making something disappear isn't enough; you have to bring it back. That's why every magic trick has a third act, the hardest part, the part we call "The Prestige"."

One of the most beautiful bird I've ever seen personally.
It grabbed my fingers with its claws so tight (but not painful) that I had to pry every toe one by one to get him off. He was in lots of pain, I'm sure. Bleeding wing.
The rehabber sorted it but it doesn't fly well anymore. Only short distances.

Anyway, I hope it remembers me and my good intentions. He's safe and well fed now. Not caged. He can fly away if he wants, but he can't really.
